We investigate the application of a Fourier transform \( \\mathcal{F}(T(x,t)) \) to convert spatial components of the heat distribution into the frequency domain at time \( t = 0 \).

Can the original temperature distribution \( T(x,0) \) be precisely reconstructed from \( T(x,T) \) without knowing that \( \\mathcal{F} \) was applied at \( t = 0 \)?
Explanation: Without knowledge of the Fourier transform application, restoring the original \( T(x,0) \) from \( T(x,T) \) is not feasible. The transformation could complicate the back-propagation of the heat equation, obscuring the true initial state.
